title: How to rise into the upper class, coming from a lower-middle class family - Quora

response.answer_text: I agree somewhat with the other answer that suggests you have to consider it a long term, pre-adulthood interaction but there are ways. One, you’re going to have to abandon your lower-middle-class family/roots. They can’t come with you. They are like a form of cancer. They carry values, mores, mindsets that are counter-productive to social mobility. This is the main reason why you most people don’t move. The current statistic is about 18% move from Poverty to Middle Class. From Middle Class to Upper Class (Rich) is about 30%. Two, you have to understand the definitional boundaries of that where you seek to move from and then to. Like any journey you’ll have to be specific is what your steps and landmarks look like. Poverty is earning under $18k-30k for a single person/family of 4. The Middle class is $30k to $250k earned annually for an individual/family of 4. Upper Middle Class starts at $250k to $1 but again, that’s continuously yearly sustained income. Upper Class is, therefore, the previous and the next two: Rich which is earning $1 million or more a year continuously. Wealthy is earning $10 million a year or more.  Financial Social class related to socioeconomics collapses to 3 levels Poor, Middle Class and Rich/Wealthy but you can see how they are broken down within the broad 3 levels. You can achieve Upper Middle Classhood working a MC job as a two-person household saving into a reasonable pension/401k and purchasing a home that has 20–40 years to accrue in value. You and a partner will have to have jobs that start at a decent level of $36k+ and increase over time. You’ll have to be thoughtful about having children. Children cost approximately $10k to $25k a year until 18 and then there are potential college costs—-each child can cost as much as $500k for 1–25 years. They too are an investment because you’re trying to get them to a higher level than you by having a greater push-off in life. Children are an emotional asset but a financial liability. They become stressful when there hasn’t been thought and planning about them before, way before they’re present. They are essentially people you must legally support for 18 years..because they’re related to you. The thoughtfulness comes in regarding how many children you have. Note this: poor people exacerbate and trap themselves into Poverty by having children they cannot afford. Each child has to be looked at as a yearly $25k BILL DUE. Which is why the Middle-Class paradigm is structured around 2 children, you need more resources per child. And now you see why you have to edit your lower-class origins/family into your life, because they, thinking against or being ignorant of the conscious realization of children as a financial expense, will encourage MORE children for a variety of reasons that are counter to financial planning and progress. Where you live also builds into your gross and net worth. You’ll have to consider the type of work you do and the type of money you’re looking to generate. There are at least 10–15 cities in America that are increasing in their financial capacity, safety, personal luxuries, and new industry. Slow Track. If you’re looking to start a career, then you have to consider law (law enforcement), healthcare, technology/IT are the areas of future growth always in society at normal rates.Medium Track. Real estate, finance and financial management/estate management of wealth people are medium track. These jobs aggregate the needs of society but can take longer to manifest.Fast Track is entrepreneurship, investing, high-risk jobs, extensive travel jobs, jobs that require knowledge of multiple languages/cultures. These jobs also include Medium Track but somehow infuse risk and speed to them.You and a partner that you have now or in the future—-will have to be on the same page about money, work, owning a business, investing, long term goals. Everyone wants “it” but doesn’t understand it’s a 10–25-year endeavor financially.  Socially/Politically You will have to move into circles that include both politicians, business owners, and professional people. Which means you’ll also need mentors. The first level of mentors you'll find will have been on a school-university level and you’ll have to maintain and nurture those relationships. Class movement is dependent upon relationships because you’ll be introduced to higher and higher levels. You’ll have to become a climber, perhaps even before you have money. Which will mean you’ll have to acquire skills and knowledge of the Upper Class around art, real estate, provenance, manners, etiquette classes/training, a legacy so that you know what they’re saying around you and what you’re trying to achieve., Join school boards, community boards, library and university boards. Travel As soon as you can, even if you don’t have money, travel to different places in the world. Being Upper Class is not just monetary it’s also mentality and world view. Clothing Classic, well made, tailored. You can dress the part with a gradual purchasing of classic, good clothing that fits you well and isn’t ostentatious. Therapy You will need a Life Coach and a psychologist to both motivate you and help you emotionally deal with ultimately changing and leaving people behind. The redesign of yourself will be grueling but it’s entirely possible with help. Tastes Your tastes in music, art, entertainment will not have to so much change as expand. The opera, musical concerts of classical music, knowing classical music, art galleries will become things you’ll have to attend and understand. Networking For men, it’s generally golf, for women it generally involves charitable works. You will also have to learn to attend the right kinds of sporting events aside from football and baseball. This will include professional mixers, conferences, wealth seminars. Climbers show up at these places and make themselves useful in the environment. Education If you have to educate at a state level, extension course at an Ivy League college or do a Masters. I tell my students at Columbia, 50% of the reason why parents send their children there is for the education—-the other 50% is to mate with/be available to the other kinds of “right” children. You’ll have to think of this for yourself and for a mate and for your children. Romeo and Juliet's bullshit goes out the window when you’re considering if it’s not just a good match but also a beneficial one to the family and the future. This means perhaps even gently molding your children to as my mother always admonished me: “Fuck up, never fuck down.” Royalty/Ancestral Heritage You can buy a title and to move through upper society you might consider it. But you would definitely have to know your family's origins. Race, Gender, Sexuality, Transsexuality It’s possible and being White makes it easier but it’s possible for all races, though if you’re not White, you have to open your romantic interests racially and age-wise. The same goes for young women and gay men and women. I would think that the hardest it would be possible to move would be a trans person unless they were born into wealth (Chaz Bono) or had a great financial, social, etc achievement prior to transitioning (Caitlyn Jenner). It’s difficult and you have to answer what the “level:” is you’re trying to achieve because it’s clear but amorphous depending upon where you are in the US or abroad. The greatest difficulty, slightly riding along with the other answer, is learning, absorbing so much “difference” compared to where you started. It’s easier to shift classes, to be accepted if you move in circles like country clubs, concerts, art, manners/etiquette—-like I did as a child form my parents and grandparents—-but it, the mindset, can be learned. You would do best to study social class first because there are Hidden Rules to class and class movement and classes. If you don’t know them then you don’t understand what you’re doing right, wrong or counterproductively. Yes, balling this all together with the above studying and movements and socialization, you’ll have to understand class societies too. But I can tell you from personal experience it’s fun, worth it and something you can choose to have as much as you like and then back off. You also will discover a different experience of life or a mandate of personal development because you’ll begin to understand how Poverty isn’t about simply money and resources, it’s about limiting human potential and development. Hopefully, the social class movement will then make you want to turn around and help others upgrade and move because you’ll explicitly know what’s required. That’s some of what I try to do with my students in all of the classes, programs, universities—-it’s really the biggest obstacle to class movement—-lack of awareness about class structures and obstacles themselves. #KylePhoenix #TheKylePhoenixShow

I grew up on TV dinners…mmm Salisbury Steak! Climbing the economic ladder is a simple concept that anyone with an exceptional work ethic and a plan can do. I didn’t go to College and my grades in Highschool weren’t great but from the age of 18 I busted my hump. My record week was 128hrs worked from 4 different jobs and I saved. No habitual drains on my check and no needless spending took me from the bottom 20% to the top 20%. You will not get there any other way… Even with a wealthy start, you are more likely to lose it than to keep or grow it. 80% of all millionaires and billionaires are first generation with over 20% of them immigrants where English is not even their first language. We all share the same ethic… postponing immediate gratifications for long term rewards and doing what the guy next to you won’t. After all, it is a “grade curve” that we all find ourselves on and if you are better at this game and play it harder than others you will have more. If you are from a Socialist country then this does apply to you as it becomes much more difficult to jump classes in an overly rigged system.

Should you suddenly acquire an immense amount of money you would simply be a wealthy middle class person. You would not be upper class. In order to become upper class you would have to go back in time to attend the correct schools, develop the manners and mannerisms of the upper class. As a fully-formed middle class adult you have an integral set of attitudes, values, mores, manners, speech patterns, vocabulary use that collectively define you. You cannot unlearn all of these and substitute another set. You cannot intercalate yourself into another social set where you don’t know anybody. What is possible, is to lose some of the more defining attributes of the middle class. Move to another area. You could become more or less “classless” or at least hard to define.

Answering questions about the wealthy trying to economically enslave the working middle class does not imply I am of the rich and powerful self-appointing class of super self-righteous eugenic snobs. If you are not one of the ‘one percenters’ you are already one of the unrepresented long-forgotten middle class. How do you climb up the middle-class cast system forced upon us… Hard work helps… Thoughtful wisdom and working wisely in that work does wonders. Never work for someone obviously using you to make themselves ever more wealthy without any consideration to your needs or desires. If the job has no practical usable benefits, then you would be better off working for yourself selling apples on the street… But I think you can do much better than that over time, in ponderous contemplation. Businesses that really prosper help other people, earn loyalty, and never cheat the customer or scam them… Have a good afternoon…

How do I change from the middle class into the upper class? Strictly speaking, you cannot do it. What you can do is start adopting the appropriate lifestyle, amassing the appropriate fortune, pass this all on to your children in such a manner that they pass it on to their children, and about 100 years hence, whatever generation of your family is alive at that time will be able to qualify as upper class, assuming they have held onto the values you originally passed down to your children, and have wisely managed the fortune bequeathed to them.

My brother, a minister's son, was dating a girl whose father was a janitor. When they graduated he went to college, her Parents told her: “Girls don't go to college.” They eventually married. She supported them both in college. Once he was out she also worked but spent about 8 years working on a degree. Both did well & have some great children & grandchildren. My brother died several years ago at 68. She has interesting hobbies; active in church & travels somewhat; grandchild chauffeur to dance classes, soccer practice, etc.

Most people who climb up do it through education. The more math a job requires (outside of teaching), the more it generally pays. So, studying is the fastest way to success. Engineering and Accounting are a couple of fields that most people avoid but pay well. So, education, specifically maths will go a long way to bringing you up the economic ladder.
